newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela's Lake Maracaibo draught may rise soon.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela's Lake Maracaibo draught may rise soon.

text.p: The maximum draught in Venezuela's Lake Maracaibo shipping channel could be increased by one foot to 37 foot after the Navy completes a survey of the channel floor within the next week or so, shipping sources in Maracaibo said on Thursday.
A naval oceanographic vessel arrived in the lake on Wednesday and was expected to start the sonar survey this weekend.
The channel which is used for over half of Venezuela's oil exports hit the headlines this year when three tankers ran aground seriously within two months, one spilling at least 25,000 barrels of oil.

The channel's draught was reduced from 39.5 foot to 36 foot at high tide after the main ship pilots' union in the area threatened to strike over the the poor state of dredging in the channel and police harrasment.

Ship brokers say each foot of draught equates to about 20,000 barrels of oil cargo per ship, depending on the density of the crude, and the current restriction means each tanker can load about 60,000 barrels less oil than usual.
At first this led to a drop of up to 150,000 barrels per day in oil exports, shipping sources said, but now they say more vessels are being chartered to shift the crude, albeit at a higher cost.
